title: AMD Ryzen 7 5700X vs Ryzen 7 5700X3D - gaming or not?
text: We decide which AMD processor is the best gaming CPU for you PC Guide is reader-supported. When you buy through links on our site, we may earn an affiliate commission. Prices subject to change. Read More Last Updated on February 1, 2024 AMD continues to push boundaries with its Ryzen processors. The latest CPU release, the Ryzen 7 5700X3D, will be available for purchase on January 31st, 2024. The new CPU is said to have the AMD 3D V-Cache for better gaming performance, but how does it fare against the widely acclaimed gaming CPU AMD Ryzen 7 5700X? Let’s compare the Ryzen 7 5700X vs Ryzen 7 5700X3D to see which is more suitable for gaming; covering their specs, performance, and price. Let’s jump right in! Both processors share the same AM4 socket and 7nm process size, highlighting AMD’s commitment to platform continuity and advanced manufacturing technology. However, when we delve deeper into the details, differences emerge. The Ryzen 7 5700X boasts 4,150 million transistors, a base clock of 3.4 GHz, and a turbo clock of 4.6 GHz. On the other hand, the Ryzen 7 5700X3D steps up the transistor count to 8,850 million but sacrifices some clock speed with a base clock of 3 GHz and a turbo clock of 4.1 GHz. These variations suggest that while the 5700X3D may have more transistors, the 5700X might offer a slight edge in raw clock speeds. Shop on Amazon Shop on Amazon Despite these disparities, both CPUs share the same 8-core, 16-thread configuration and similar cache structures for L1 and L2. The previous AMD CPU is also power efficient compared to the upcoming release. It has a TDP of 65 W, much lower than AMD Ryzen 7 5700X3D’s 105 W. In terms of cache, the 5700X3D takes a commanding lead with 96 MB of shared L3 cache compared to the 32 MB on the 5700X. This substantial difference could impact tasks that rely heavily on cache, such as video editing and rendering. The Ryzen 7 5700X boasts a higher base clock of 3.4 GHz than the Ryzen 7 5700X3D, which has a base clock of 3 GHz. This means that the 5700X might have a slight edge regarding single-core performance and responsiveness, or so it may appear. While the Ryzen 7 5700X has higher clock speeds, the Ryzen 7 5700X3D is powered by the 3D V-Cache™ technology. Hence why, when considering gaming performance, the Ryzen 7 5700X3D with its 96 MB shared L3 cache is the clear winner. The cache memory is vital for ensuring the data, required in real time for gaming, is quickly available to the CPU. The addition of the V-Cache provides gamers with a massive boost to prevent lags and ensure a seamless experience. AMD stays true to its affordability mantra even with the new release. Price is often a decisive factor when choosing a processor. In this aspect, the Ryzen 7 5700X3D takes the lead with a lower price tag of $249 compared to the $299 of the 5700X. This price difference could be a significant factor for budget-conscious users or those looking for maximum value for their money. Considering the performance differences and the varying cache sizes, users should weigh their priorities between raw power and cost-effectiveness. If gaming and high single-core performance are top priorities, the Ryzen 7 5700X3D might be the better choice, primarily because of the V-Cache technology. On the other hand, users with tasks that benefit from multi-core performance may find the Ryzen 7 5700X more appealing. So there you have it! If you’re trying to decide between these two AMD CPUs; we would recommend going with the AMD Ryzen 7 5700X3D. This new release certainly has lower clock speeds and higher TDP. However, it has a higher transistor count and L3 cache memory, which can be a game-changer for gaming enthusiasts. Ultimately, the choice between the AMD Ryzen 7 5700X and Ryzen 7 5700X3D depends on individual preferences, budget constraints, and the intended use of the processor.
